III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
New Directions Livonia is an open community-based setting located in a single
building at 33600 Luther Lane, Livonia, MI 48154. The facility has been fully
renovated with updated flooring, bedrooms, bathrooms, a lounge area, game
room, dining area, and kitchen. The main entrance is limited to staff, emergency
personnel, and guests, the main entrance leads to administrative offices, family
visiting room, and the conference room. Once past the main entrance there is a
second set of doors that lead to the four units, each unit has six bedrooms, each
bedroom has its own private bathroom, twin-size bed, nightstand, a built-in desk,
and shelving unit. The bedrooms have a window and are very spacious. All doors
open out to prevent youth barricading in the rooms. Bedroom doors are equipped
with a sensor for room check monitoring for when youths are in their bedroom and
during sleeping hours. This system allows records of doing room checks of
intervals not more than 15 minutes. Each unit has its own washer and dryer,
supply room, staff desk, and two lounge areas with a television. There is a second
exit door off each unit. The dining room and kitchen is accessible from the area off
the four units. There are two outdoor courtyards and two game rooms that can be
accessed from the dining area. There is also a basketball court and additional
space outdoors for recreational activities. Every interior and exterior part of the
facility is monitored by CCTV with several angles except the bedrooms,

B. Program Description
The program statement has been reviewed, and the following information has
been summarized to detail the facility’s program.
New Direction is a residential treatment program that provides comprehensive
residential treatment designed to meet the needs of those dually diagnosed
(defined as the presence of cognitive impairment or other developmental disability
co-occurring with a behavioral, psychiatric, or emotional disorder) and a
specialized developmental disabilities unit (AKA “Autism” unit). The capacity is 24
youths, co-ed, and the age range is 12-17. The facility has four separate units,
each unit has six bedrooms and a lounge area. The supervision ratio is one staff
to every two youths, and one staff to every six youths during sleeping hours. The
program is contracted with the State of Michigan to provide residential treatment
services to Cognitively Impaired/Developmentally Disabled youth. This includes
mild or moderately intellectually impaired children with a FSIQ between 45 and
69. Youth with classic autism spectrum disorder that restricts functioning and
multiply impaired youth with cognitive and physical impairments.
The youths present with educational classification as cognitively impaired, autism
spectrum disorder, learning disabled, emotionally impaired, or physically and or
otherwise health impaired or are eligible for such classification before being
considered for admission so that their educational needs can be met in a public-
school setting. The facility offers year-round individual tutoring and remediation
with certified special education teachers through EPIC.
The facility will provide individual, group and family therapy, case management,
and individualized treatment plans developed by master’s level Clinicians using a
trauma-informed, strength-based, and person-centered planning approach, after
hours and weekend family therapy. Therapists complete course work after hire on
Cognitive Behavioral approaches to the treatment of trauma. All staff are trained
to provide a treatment environment and treatment that reflects the understanding
the profound neurological, biological, psychological, and social effects of trauma
on youth.
The structure and design of the program allow for each youth to have
opportunities to interact in a daily 24/7 supervised residential living environment
while maintaining a level of therapeutic independence with the group.
3

The agency will utilize Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) as their emergency
intervention techniques. All staff are trained on the physical and verbal de-
escalation techniques in this model. CPI refreshers are conducted annually. The
program’s crisis de-escalation and behavior management program (NVPCI) is
taught in tandem with the NVPCI Trauma care training assuring that maximum
care is taken to avoid re-traumatizing residents with physical management.
Spiritual services will be provided to those youth who would like to participate in
religious activities.
The facility will provide medical through Trinity Hospital of Livonia, and Dental
Care of Michigan. There is also a registered nurse onsite 40 hours a week.
The facility will provide recreational and community activities through the Livonia
Recreational Center and will participate in Livonia Unified Special Olympics sports
activities. The facility will also provide art therapy for youths benefitting most from
non-verbal treatment approaches.
All new employees will receive 50 hours of training within the first year and 25
hours annually in accordance with licensing rules.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
All policies and procedures have been reviewed and are in compliance with
licensing rules and statutes.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
original license be issued.
